title: My 4-Year-Old Wants to Learn Soroban – Is It Too Early?
description: Soroban starts at age 5-6 in Japan. But what if your preschooler is curious? Here's what actually works for young learners.

content.intro: My daughter Sophie is 4 and incredibly curious about numbers. She saw a soroban on YouTube and has been begging to try it. But most programs say ages 5-7. Is she too young? Here's what I learned.

items: **Fine motor skills:** Moving small beads requires developed finger control
**Number recognition:** Kids need to know numbers 0-9 at minimum
**Attention span:** Even short lessons need 10-15 minutes of focus
Has good fine motor control (can draw, use scissors)
Can focus on one activity for 10+ minutes

sections.text: Interest is the biggest indicator. A curious 4-year-old will learn more than a reluctant 6-year-old.
I didn't push Sophie into a full program. Instead, we started with:

items: **Playing with the abacus:** Just exploring, moving beads, making sounds
**Color games:** We got a colorful abacus first
**Short sessions:** 5 minutes max, always ending before she got bored

sections.text: ✅ **Worked:** Treating it like a toy, not school. No pressure, no "lessons."
✅ **Worked:** Following her lead. Some days she wanted 15 minutes, some days 2.
❌ **Didn't work:** Trying to teach "proper technique" too early.
❌ **Didn't work:** Formal app lessons – too structured for her age.
At 4: Keep it playful. Count beads. Make it fun.
At 5: Try the app's easiest level. See if she's ready.
No rush. The goal isn't to create a prodigy – it's to build a foundation where math feels fun, not scary.
There's no prize for starting earliest. A child who starts at 6 and loves it will outperform one who started at 4 and burned out.

faq.question: Can a 3-year-old learn soroban?
faq.answer: It's very early. Most 3-year-olds don't have the fine motor skills or attention span. Exposure is fine, but structured learning usually waits until 5+.

faq.question: Should I buy a real soroban for my preschooler?
faq.answer: A toy abacus with larger, colorful beads is better for ages 3-4. Real sorobans have small beads that can frustrate little fingers.

faq.question: What if my 4-year-old loses interest?
faq.answer: That's completely normal. Put it away for 3-6 months and try again. Interest often returns when they're developmentally ready.
